definitions: make something move or happen more slowly than normal or expected
prevent or slow down the natural development or growth of something
examples: Heavy traffic will retard our arrival at the airport
The thick mud retarded the soldiers' advance through the field
Poor nutrition can retard a child's physical and mental development
Lack of sunlight will retard the growth of these plants

definitions: think carefully about something again especially to change your opinion or plans
examples: We need to rethink our marketing strategy for next year
After the accident, she decided to rethink her career choices

definitions: say something quick and sharp or angry in response to what someone said
examples: She retorted that the mistake was his fault not hers
When criticized, he retorted with a clever comeback that silenced everyone

definitions: go back over the same route or path that you already traveled
examples: We had to retrace our steps to find the lost keys
The detective retraced the victim's movements on the day of disappearance

definitions: formally take back or withdraw a statement promise or accusation
draw back or pull in a part of the body or mechanism
examples: The newspaper had to retract the false story about the politician
After public outcry, the company retracted its controversial policy announcement
The cat can retract its claws when playing gently
The landing gear retracts into the plane after takeoff

definitions: move back or withdraw especially from something dangerous difficult or unpleasant
go away to a quiet or private place for rest reflection or escape
examples: The army had to retreat when enemy reinforcements arrived
She retreated from the argument before it became too heated
Every summer they retreat to their cabin in the mountains
The monks retreat to the monastery for prayer and meditation

definitions: add new or modified parts equipment or features to something old
examples: The building was retrofitted with earthquake-resistant supports last year
They retrofitted the old car with modern safety features

definitions: move backward or in reverse direction especially in orbit or rotation
go back to an earlier and usually worse state or condition
examples: Mercury appears to retrograde several times each year from Earth's perspective
The planet's retrograde motion puzzled ancient astronomers for centuries
The country's economy began to retrograde after the trade war started
His health seemed to retrograde despite the medical treatment

definitions: think about or consider something that happened in the past
examples: In retrospect, we should have left the party much earlier
She often retrospects about her college days with fondness

definitions: make another attempt to do something after a previous attempt failed
examples: Please retry entering your password if it was incorrect
The court decided to retry the case with new evidence

definitions: come together or bring people together again after being separated
examples: The family will reunite for grandmother's ninetieth birthday celebration
The organization works to reunite lost pets with their owners

definitions: use something again instead of throwing it away or getting new
examples: We always reuse plastic containers for storing leftovers
The artist likes to reuse old materials in her sculptures

definitions: increase the running speed of an engine by pressing the accelerator
examples: He revved the motorcycle engine to warm it up
Stop revving the car engine while it's parked outside

definitions: give new and improved form structure or appearance to something
examples: The company plans to revamp its website next month
They revamped the old theater into a modern concert hall

definitions: take great pleasure or delight in something
enjoy yourself in a lively noisy way especially with drinking and dancing
examples: She revels in the beauty of nature during her hikes
The team reveled in their championship victory all night
The students reveled until dawn after finishing their exams
Ancient Romans would revel during their festival celebrations

definitions: feel deep respect admiration and honor for someone or something
examples: Many people revere the civil rights leader for her courage
The ancient civilization revered the sun as a god

definitions: treat someone or something with deep respect honor and admiration
examples: The students reverence their elderly professor for his wisdom
Many cultures reverence their ancestors through special ceremonies

definitions: return to a previous state condition practice or belief after a change
examples: The software will revert to default settings after the update
After trying city life, he reverted to his rural roots

definitions: examine and make corrections or improvements to written or printed material
study material again especially in preparation for an examination
examples: The author needs to revise the manuscript before publication
Please revise your essay to fix the grammar errors
Students should revise their notes before the final exam
She spent all weekend revising for her chemistry test

definitions: go back to a place that you have been to before
think about discuss or consider something again especially from new perspective
examples: We plan to revisit Paris on our anniversary next year
The author revisited her childhood home for inspiration
Let's revisit this decision after we have more information
The committee will revisit the proposal at next month's meeting

definitions: give new life energy or strength to something that was weak or declining
examples: The new investment will revitalise the struggling downtown area
A good vacation can revitalise your mind and body

definitions: bring new life and energy to something that has become weak tired or declining
examples: The mayor's plan aims to revitalize the city's economy
Regular exercise helps revitalize your energy levels throughout the day

definitions: bring someone back to consciousness or life from near death
bring something back into use activity or popularity after decline
examples: The paramedics managed to revive the drowning victim
Cold water on her face helped revive the fainting woman
The director hopes to revive interest in classic theater
The band decided to revive their hit song from the eighties

definitions: officially cancel or take away a decision law license or agreement
examples: The court may revoke his driver's license for repeated violations
The university threatened to revoke her scholarship for poor grades

definitions: take violent action against an authority or government in rebellion
feel strong disgust or shock about something unpleasant or wrong
examples: The citizens revolted against the oppressive government regime
The workers revolted when their wages were cut unfairly
The graphic images of violence revolted viewers across the nation
The smell of rotting garbage revolted everyone in the neighborhood

definitions: change something completely and fundamentally especially in ways that bring major improvements
examples: The internet has revolutionized how people communicate and shop
This new technology could revolutionize the medical industry

definitions: move in a circular orbit around a central point or axis
have something as the main or central theme element or concern
examples: The Earth revolves around the sun once every year
The dancers revolve gracefully around the stage during the performance
Her entire life revolves around caring for her children
The discussion revolved around finding solutions to climate change

definitions: wind a tape or film back to an earlier point or the beginning
examples: Please rewind the video to the part we missed
Kids today don't understand having to rewind VHS tapes

definitions: make changes to something especially to improve it or make it suitable
examples: The designer had to rework the logo several times
She needs to rework her thesis statement for clarity

definitions: write something again in a different or improved way
examples: The editor asked me to rewrite the opening paragraph
History books often rewrite events from different perspectives

definitions: have or end with the same or similar sound as another word
put words together that have the same or similar ending sounds
examples: The word 'cat' rhymes with 'hat' and 'mat'
In poetry, the last words of lines often rhyme
Children love to rhyme words when learning to read
The songwriter struggled to rhyme lyrics for the chorus

definitions: make fun of someone in a friendly joking way
examples: His friends always rib him about his fear of spiders
She gently ribbed her brother about his new haircut

definitions: bounce or skip off a surface at an angle after hitting it
examples: The bullet ricocheted off the metal wall dangerously
Stones ricochet across the water when you skip them

definitions: make many holes in something especially with bullets
fill or permeate something completely with something undesirable
examples: The old target was riddled with bullet holes from practice
Termites had riddled the wooden beams with tiny holes
The report was riddled with spelling and grammar errors
His argument was riddled with logical fallacies and contradictions

definitions: make someone or something seem foolish by making fun of them unkindly
examples: The bullies would ridicule him for his old-fashioned clothes
Critics ridiculed the mayor's proposal as completely unrealistic

definitions: play a short repeated phrase of music especially in jazz or rock
talk or develop ideas in an informal unplanned way about topic
examples: The guitarist loves to riff during the instrumental breaks
Jazz musicians often riff on classic melodies during performances
The comedian likes to riff on current events during shows
Let me riff on that idea for a few minutes

definitions: turn over pages quickly and casually when looking through something
shuffle playing cards by bending and releasing them so they intermix
examples: She riffled through the magazine looking for the article
He nervously riffled through his notes before the presentation
The dealer expertly riffled the deck before dealing cards
Learn to riffle shuffle to impress at poker games

definitions: set up equipment or machinery especially for temporary use
arrange or influence something dishonestly to get desired result
examples: The crew needs to rig the stage for tonight's concert
Sailors must know how to rig the sails properly
They accused him of trying to rig the election results
The game show was rigged to let certain contestants win

definitions: form or be positioned around the edge or border of something
examples: Snow rimmed the mountain peaks in brilliant white
Tears rimmed her eyes as she heard the sad news

definitions: cover something with a coating of frost or ice crystals
examples: Winter fog had rimed the tree branches with white crystals
The cold morning rimed every surface with delicate frost

definitions: wash something quickly with clean water to remove soap dirt or other substances
examples: Remember to rinse the dishes before putting them in dishwasher
She rinses her hair thoroughly after applying the conditioner

definitions: become or make fruit or crops ready to eat through natural development
examples: The bananas will ripen faster in a paper bag
Tomatoes ripen best when left on the vine

definitions: form or cause small waves on the surface of water
spread through or affect something gradually like waves spreading outward
examples: The stone made the water ripple in expanding circles
A gentle breeze rippled across the wheat field
News of the scandal rippled through the small town quickly
The economic crisis rippled across global markets

definitions: fasten or join metal parts together using a metal pin or bolt
hold someone's attention completely so they cannot look away
examples: Workers riveted the steel beams together for the bridge
The panels were riveted to the aircraft's frame securely
The speaker's dramatic story riveted the audience's attention
Her eyes were riveted on the thrilling movie scene

definitions: cut a horse's mane very short so it stands upright
examples: The groomer will roach the show horse's mane tomorrow
Some riders prefer to roach their horse's mane for easier care

definitions: move about or travel with no fixed purpose or direction
examples: Wild horses roam freely across the open prairie lands
She likes to roam through antique shops on weekends

definitions: make a loud deep sound like a lion or thunder
laugh very loudly and heartily at something funny
examples: The lion roared to warn intruders away from its territory
Thunder roared across the sky during the violent storm
The audience roared at the comedian's hilarious joke
He roared with laughter when he heard the funny story

definitions: cook food especially meat in an oven or over fire with dry heat
criticize or make fun of someone in a humorous way especially publicly
examples: We plan to roast a turkey for Thanksgiving dinner
She likes to roast vegetables with olive oil and herbs
His friends love to roast him at his birthday party
The comedian roasted celebrities at the awards show

definitions: dress someone or yourself in long loose ceremonial garments
examples: The judge robed himself before entering the courtroom
Priests robe in special garments for religious ceremonies

definitions: play or move about in a lively energetic and boisterous way
examples: The puppies romp around the yard chasing each other
Children love to romp in the playground after school
